item.title: Pokemon Legends: Z-A is Saying Goodbye to 1 Mega Evolution
item.description:
Pokemon Legends: Z-A will apparently be bringing back all of the Mega Evolutions from X and Y and Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire , minus Mega Rayquaza. Like with most other Pokemon games, there have been plenty of leaks about the upcoming Pokemon Legends: Z-A and what exactly the new game will entail. Now that the game is in the hands of some players that have managed to get early copies, datamining leaks have revealed even more details about the game.

As one might imagine, a lot of the leaks have revolved around the Pokemon that will be featured in Pokemon Legends: Z-A and the new Mega Evolutions that the game is introducing to the franchise. Descriptions of many Pokemon Legends: Z-A Mega Evolutions leaked ahead of their proper reveals and have proven to be largely accurate. The latest leak doesn't reveal any more Mega Evolution designs, but it does reveal one Mega Evolution that won't be featured in the new game.

Pokemon Legends: Z-A Won't Have Mega Rayquaza

According to Centro Leaks on Twitter, Pokemon Legends: Z-A will not bring back Mega Rayquaza. All the other Mega Evolutions from X and Y and Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire are expected to return, meaning Mega Rayquaza is the only one being left behind. In fact, Rayquaza is apparently not in Pokemon Legends: Z-A at all. It's unclear why this is, but there's always a chance that Rayquaza and its Mega Evolution will be added through some kind of post-launch event or paid DLC.

We already know that Game Freak and Nintendo have big plans for Pokemon Legends: Z-A post-launch. The Mega Dimension DLC has already been announced and will introduce two Mega Evolutions for Raichu alongside a new storyline for fans to complete. Who's to say that Mega Rayquaza can't show up in DLC of its own. It would be strange for Mega Rayquaza to be the only one left out of Pokemon Legends: Z-A , so hopefully the popular legendary gets the comeback it deserves.

The wait for Pokemon Legends: Z-A is nearly at an end, with the highly-anticipated RPG set to launch on October 16. At launch, Pokemon Legends: Z-A will have both Switch 1 and Switch 2 versions available, with pre-orders varying by retailer. Needless to say, Pokemon fans have a lot of tough decisions to make about the game beyond what starter they will choose, but regardless, the next Pokemon adventure is right around the corner.

Pokemon Legends: Z-A

item.title: Battlefield 6 is Absolutely Blowing Up on Steam
item.description:
Battlefield 6 has been a huge hit on Steam, with over 700,000 simultaneous gamers playing it on the platform less than an hour after release. With a serious tone, explosive gameplay, and action-packed multiplayer, EA’s Battlefield 6 seems to be just what the fanbase wanted.

Ever since Electronic Arts started ramping up Battlefield 6 marketing earlier this year, it has been clear that the first-person shooter would be a major success. This expectation was met when Battlefield 6 peaked at over 520,000 concurrent players on Steam during the open beta, but it became even clearer with the game’s official launch.

Battlefield 6 Surpasses 740,000 Simultaneous Players on Steam

Data from SteamDB indicates that Battlefield 6 currently has 747,440 simultaneous players on Steam at the time of this report, and the number will likely continue to grow. The popular FPS managed to get over 700,000 simultaneous players in less than an hour after release, indicating that many were just expecting the title to be ready to dive in. It’s expected that these numbers could get even higher during the weekend. An analyst has also indicated that Battlefield 6 has made over $100 million solely on Steam during the first day. The numbers of players and revenue look even more incredible when considering that data for PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S are currently not available.

Unfortunately, not everything about the launch has been entirely positive so far. As soon as the game launched, reports indicated that Battlefield 6 experienced server overload. In mere minutes, a server queue of over 280,000 gamers formed, which is disappointing news for anyone who was looking to play. The same also happened during the Battlefield 6 beta, but fortunately, the queues were emptied quite quickly. It’s unknown if the same will happen with the full launch, but it’s expected that most issues will be fixed in a few hours, and the experience will be better soon.

Overall, early opinions on Battlefield 6 have been incredibly positive, as the title currently stands with an average critic score of 84 on OpenCritic. While most reviewers have praised Battlefield 6 ’s overall gameplay and the destructive nature of the multiplayer, which offers a nice variety of maps, others have criticized its single-player campaign for not standing out enough. In any case, it looks like anyone eager to play multiplayer in Battlefield 6 will have a fairly busy weekend, as more and more gamers flock to the popular title.

10 /10
9 /10

Battlefield 6

item.title: Where to Find the Mother of Thorns in Fortnite (Fortnitemares)
item.description:
Fortnitemares 2025 makes its grand debut at the tail end of Fortnite Chapter 6 Season 4, bringing Halloween festivities into the game with plenty of spooky scares and unique content. Those jumping into Reload will be greeted by Nitemare Island for a fresh round of competitive action, while Battle Royale also receives new content with items like the Last Call and returning loot such as the Pumpkin Launcher.

When it comes to Fortnitemares Battle Royale content, bosses have set up base across the island, leading to intense battles and the chance to earn powerful Mythic loot. Doja Cat herself can be defeated in-game and grants players access to the Thorn Ripper, a unique version of the Chains of Hades. Here’s where to find the Mother of Thorns in Fortnitemares.

Where to Find the Mother of Thorns in Fortnite

The Mother of Thorns is one of the many bosses players can encounter during the Fortnitemares 2025 Event. Unlike most past Fortnite bosses, she doesn’t spawn in just one set location. Instead, the Mother of Thorns can appear in several areas across the island, with her spawn point changing from match to match. Her location will be marked on the player’s map as a skull icon once they get close enough.

Players can also hear music that plays when they are near her, making it a little easier to track her down when heading to a specific POI. Keep in mind, the Mother of Thorns can only be encountered once per match , so once she is defeated, she won’t respawn until you load into a new Battle Royale game.

Here are all the possible spawn locations where the Mother of Thorns can appear:

  • Freaky Fields
  • Gourdy Gate
  • Thorny Throne (POI west of Supernova Academy)

All Rewards for Defeating the Mother of Thorns in Fortnite

The Mother of Thorns boss is fairly easy to defeat during Fortnitemares and can be taken down quickly with a few well-placed headshots. Once defeated, she will drop her signature Thorn Ripper Mythic Weapon , which works similarly to the Chains of Hades. Players can use it to pull in enemies and nearby loot by pressing the Shoot Button while aiming, or deal melee damage by pressing the Shoot Button without aiming.

After being defeated, the Mother of Thorns will also join your squad , functioning like a hired NPC and using her own weapons to assist in battle. Here is a quick rundown of all the items players can earn by defeating the Mother of Thorns in Fortnite :

  • Thorn Ripper (Mythic)
  • Wooden Stake Shotgun (Epic)
  • Slurp Juice (Legendary)
  • Gold
  • Ammunition

item.title: New Sims Game Isn’t For Everyone, But It’s Perfect for Me
item.description:
When I recently admitted that I’ve played The Sims 4 for over 2,000 hours, someone gently pointed out that this translates to nearly 86 days of my life. It’s a number that sounds a little horrifying on paper, but also likely reasonable to anyone who’s ever lost an afternoon to a new build or a Sim’s midlife crisis. Because if I’m honest, that’s only counting The Sims 4 . If I factored in every version I’ve played, the number would be staggering: from my first foray into The Sims 2 , the more age-appropriate MySims , and finally the Christmas morning I unwrapped The Sims 4 in 2014. I’ve said " sul sul " to my fair share of simulated lives.

Still, I’ve always wished I could bring that little world with me. For all my hours spent building dream homes and ruining digital relationships in my 20s, The Sims has never truly captured that portable magic. There were DS MySims titles back in the day that I adored, but none of the later mobile spin-offs ever managed to recreate that same feeling. It’s a dream I took for granted as a kid and one I’ve quietly carried into adulthood.

That’s about to change. With EA’s recent announcement that MySims is coming to Apple Arcade, I’m preparing for what feels less like a reboot and more like a return—one that promises to shrink the cutest sandbox of nostalgia down to the size of my palm.

MySims Arrives On Apple Arcade At the Perfect Moment

MySims has been having a moment. With the release of MySims Cozy Bundle last year, its reemergence sparked a wave of nostalgia among Sims fans. Now, more Sims fans can enjoy the title, whether they played it on the DS or are simply curious about it. However, it appears that the cozy project is still gaining momentum. EA just announced that MySims is continuing its comeback, this time on Apple Arcade. MySims and MySims Kingdom will be available on Apple Arcade on November 6, 2025.

Originally released on the Nintendo DS and Wii, MySims was EA’s bright, bubbly The Sims spin-off: smaller in scale, heavier on charm, and designed for the kind of player who just wanted to vibe. Now, with its debut on Apple Arcade, that charm gets a fresh start ideally suited for touchscreens and lazy weekend gaming sessions.

For fans like me who have been dreaming of a portable The Sims title that wasn't just a mobile exclusive, it feels like a long-overdue reunion. For anyone who ever spent a Saturday afternoon decorating pastel houses and befriending the weirdest little villagers, this is our moment.

EA Joins the Cozy Mobile Gaming Race

For years, The Sims has been the cozy life-sim juggernaut that refuses to fit in your pocket, even in the face of other popular titles that do. The Sims 4 never made it to the Nintendo Switch, and its mobile spin-offs ( FreePlay , Mobile ) never quite captured the magic of the mainline experience. But MySims joining Apple Arcade might be a subtle turning point. If this is a step in a new direction, players might be watching The Sims quietly step into a new era—one where “playing God” is just as easy on the couch, on the train, or in bed.

  • A Cozy Market Dominated by Portability: Stardew Valley , Cozy Grove , and Spiritfarer are all thriving on mobile or console. In a market that can be oversaturated, sometimes, convenience may make a game stand out. And although EA is a massive player in this market, it has introduced MySims into this territory.
  • The Sims Is Finally Joining the Mobile Race : By introducing MySims on a platform like Apple Arcade, EA may measure interest in bite-sized, offline-friendly versions of The Sims .
  • A Strategic Soft Launch: This could be a low-risk way to test the appetite for portable Sims experiences before developing a full handheld entry or even considering porting The Sims 4 . With The Sims 5 not expected to arrive anytime soon, The Sims 4 faces a unique challenge in sustaining its longevity. Perhaps ports may be a solution.
  • Nostalgia with Intent : Choosing MySims doesn't seem random. It’s familiar, low-stakes, and cozy enough to pull long-time fans (and curious new players) back into the fold. It would also be a cozy title to compete directly with titles like Disney Dreamlight Valley and Hello Kitty Island Adventure in terms of structure.

MySims Is the Cozier Side of The Sims Franchise

I love The Sims. I’ve got thousands of hours to prove it. But sometimes, I want something simpler on hard days. An experience that offers the structure. Something that doesn’t ask me to manage six of my most erratic Sims’ emotional breakdowns before they head to work. That’s where MySims comes in to rescue me from the clutches of Don Lothario.

I have to acknowledge, however, that MySims isn't for every The Sims player. Players who have grown too accustomed to the vast sandbox may feel too confined by its linear storytelling, end goals, and lack of cheekier humor. But MySims is not about controlling chaos; it’s about crafting joy. And in a world full of high-stress life sims, MySims feels like a quiet, colorful exhale. It was a proper cozy game before “cozy games” became a genre, and if you're a cozy game fan, MySims may be for you.

If You’re A Longtime Sims Player, MySims is at Least Worth a Chance

MySims may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I insist that most simmers should give it a try. Especially if those simmers like to tread on the cozier side of the life sim genre. And platforms like iOS or macOS serve the game's casual nature perfectly.

  • Touchscreen Ready: The gameplay already feels tailor-made for mobile. You can literally pick up and play while curled under a blanket.
  • No Microtransactions: Apple Arcade means no ads, no waiting timers, and no requests to purchase digital currency for the best experience. This may be a welcome change of pace for those players who often miss out on The Sims 4 ’s Expansion Packs due to price tag concerns. This is a Sims game without the investment.
  • A Game That Fits the Moment: MySims is cozy, colorful, and bite-sized. Exactly what most Sims fans need in between The Sims 4 updates.
  • Room to Grow : Now that it’s back in the spotlight, there have been rumors that more classic MySims games may be making a comeback. If those rumors are true, then simmers may have a lot to look forward to. And they should absolutely explore the source materials regardless.

item.title: MindsEye Devs Publish Letter Criticizing the Company
item.description:
Current and former MindsEye developers have published an open letter criticizing Build A Rocket Boy's leadership, accusing it of mismanagement and several other missteps. The move adds to the growing list of controversies resulting from MindsEye 's launch.

First announced in March 2023, MindsEye was touted as an ambitious cyberpunk action adventure meant to put Build A Rocket Boy—a Scottish studio founded by former GTA franchise lead developer Leslie Benzies—on the map. The game was released in June 2025 to abysmal reviews and fan frustrations. Build A Rocket Boy reportedly started laying off staffers shortly thereafter.

MindsEye Staffers Allege Mishandled Layoffs and Crunch in Union-Backed Letter

On October 10, the Independent Workers of Great Britain (IWGB) union published an open letter co-signed by nearly 100 current and former Build a Rocket Buy staffers, accusing the company of mishandled layoffs and other severe missteps surrounding MindsEye 's widely panned release. The signatories allege that the studio subjected employees to four months of mandatory crunch ahead of launch, requiring eight hours of overtime per week for all staff. This extra work was reportedly compensated not with overtime pay, but with time off in lieu—at a rate of seven hours for every eight worked—and many employees have yet to take that time off because they keep getting requests for "high-priority" work, IWGB claims.

The letter also appears to confirm earlier reports that the MindsEye developer was hit with layoffs in June 2025, estimating that between 250 and 300 people have been made redundant since then. The union describes the handling of the layoffs themselves as "disastrous." According to the IWGB, the redundancies were marked by misinformation, administrative errors, and potentially wrongful dismissals—missteps that reportedly caused confusion and distress among all employees. The letter further accuses studio leadership of a lack of transparency, stating that staff were routinely given minimal information, which was subject to “radical changes” without consultation.

The undersignatories demand a public apology, proper compensation for laid-off staff, and a documented plan to improve internal processes, including union recognition. "BARB needs to change," the letter—signed by 93 current and former employees—reads. "CEOs need to take a backseat and allow the skilled people who remain at the company to forge the path ahead."

IWGB's Demands for MindsEye Developer BARB

  1. A public apology for this mistreatment of employees and proper compensation for laid-off employees;
  2. The option for remaining employees on redundancy notice to either work their notice period or take Payment in Lieu of Notice (PILON);
  3. A concerted, meaningful, and documented effort to improve conditions and processes within the company, including the acknowledgement of the IWGB as a trade union;
  4. A commitment to use official external partners to action any future redundancies and prevent unfair treatment.

BARB needs to change. CEOs need to take a backseat and allow the skilled people who remain at the company to forge the path ahead.

While highly critical in tone, the letter does not include any direct legal threats against Build A Rocket Boy. It places full responsibility for the game’s troubled launch on the studio’s leadership, without referencing its publisher, IO Interactive. IOI recently indicated that MindsEye 's underwhelming performance may end its third-party publishing experiment. BARB, for its part, reportedly has plans to relaunch the game, but details on this purported effort are currently scarce and the move itself has yet to be officially confirmed.

13
4.8 /10
